content: The Earth is now about 1.2°C warmer than in pre-industrial times.
The 10 hottest years on record have all occurred since 2010.
Arctic sea ice is shrinking by nearly 13% per decade since the 1980s.
Atmospheric CO₂ levels have exceeded 420 ppm, the highest in 800,000 years.
Oceans absorb about 90% of the excess heat from global warming.
Melting glaciers contribute over 30% to sea level rise.
Global sea levels have risen by about 20 cm since 1900.
The frequency of heatwaves has increased dramatically.
Climate change causes more intense extreme weather events.
Ocean temperatures in some regions are the warmest in over 100 years.
Coral reefs are experiencing mass bleaching due to warmer seas.
Animal migration patterns are shifting toward cooler regions.
Spring arrives earlier in many parts of the world.
Boreal forests and tundra are thawing, releasing methane from permafrost.
Pollinators like bees are declining due to changing seasons and temperatures.
Higher CO₂ makes plants grow faster but with reduced nutrients.
Marine animals are migrating poleward, destabilizing fisheries.
Crop yields are declining due to heat stress and erratic rainfall.
Diseases like malaria and dengue are spreading to new regions due to warming.
Air pollution and extreme heat increase mortality risk, especially for the elderly.
Climate change worsens conflicts and drives forced migration.
Millions have been displaced due to floods and droughts.
Rising temperatures impact youth mental health and anxiety.
Wildfires are becoming more frequent and intense globally.
Climate-related disasters cause hundreds of billions of dollars in annual losses.
Insurance companies are raising premiums or refusing to cover high-risk climate zones.
Energy costs are rising due to increased demand for air conditioning.
Tourism is affected—ski resorts suffer from less snow, coastal resorts from flooding.
Work productivity drops in hotter regions due to extreme heat.
Methane is 80 times more powerful than CO₂ over 20 years.
Warming oceans release more CO₂, worsening climate feedback loops.
Tropical forests can turn from carbon sinks to carbon sources if degraded.
Black carbon (soot) from engines and industry speeds up ice melt.
Thawing permafrost is releasing ancient viruses once frozen for millennia.
Peatland fires in Indonesia released more carbon than Japan’s total emissions that year.
A single cow can emit around 100 kg of methane per year.
The fashion industry contributes more than 10% of global greenhouse gas emissions.
Producing one smartphone generates about 50-85 kg of CO₂.
Data centers account for roughly 2% of global emissions.
Using bikes or public transport can cut your emissions by up to 1 ton per year.
Plant-based and locally sourced food has a much smaller carbon footprint.
One adult tree can absorb about 20–22 kg of CO₂ per year.
Just 100 companies are responsible for over 70% of industrial emissions since 1988.
Entire island nations like Tuvalu and the Maldives may become uninhabitable due to rising sea levels.
Saltwater intrusion from sea-level rise is contaminating freshwater sources on small islands.
Some Pacific islands are already evacuating residents due to coastal erosion and frequent flooding.
Island biodiversity is especially vulnerable many endemic species face extinction from habitat loss.
Coral reef degradation around tropical islands threatens fisheries and local economies.
Many islands depend heavily on tourism, which is declining due to climate-related damage.
Island communities often have limited resources to adapt to climate impacts compared to mainland regions.
Some islands are exploring floating infrastructure as a future proof adaptation strategy.
Climate refugees from sinking islands may face statelessness if their nations disappear.
Island mangrove forests are crucial for coastal defense but are rapidly disappearing due to warming seas.
